Compute
\[\sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}},\]where the sum is taken over all positive integers $i$ and $j$ such that $1 \le j < i.$
inference:
A typical term of the sum is $\frac{1}{2^{i + j}},$ where $1 \le j < i.$  The sum over $i$ for a fixed $j$ is a geometric series, so
$$\sum_{\ell = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^{\ell}} = \frac{1/2^{j + 1}}{1 - 1/2} = \frac{1}{2^{j}}.$$

Thus
$$\begin{split} \sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^{j}} \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^{i}} \\\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^{j}} \cdot \frac{1}{2^{j}} \\\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^{2j}} \\\ &= \frac{1}{4} \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^j \\\ &= \frac{1}{4} \left( \frac{\frac{1}{2}}{1 - \frac{1}{2}} \right) \\\ &= \frac{1}{4} \\\ &= \frac{1}{4}. \end{split}$$

Final Answer: $\boxed{\frac{1}{4}}.$ I hope it is correct.

\sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} \\
&= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^i} \\
&= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \left( \frac{1}{2^{j + 1}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 2}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 3}} + \dotsb \right) \\
&= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1/2^{j + 1}}{1 - 1/2} \\
&= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1}{2^j} \\
&= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{4^j} \\
&= \frac{1/4}{1 - 1/4} \\
&= \boxed{\frac{1}{3}}.
\end{align*}
